## Conversation that answers the provided questions:
**User:**
Hey, I've been doing some research on Verus and I'm curious about the block reward schedule. Can you explain it to me?

**AI Assistant:**
The block reward schedule for Verus is divided into Eras. In Era 1, the block reward rises linearly from 0 to 384 over the first 10,080 blocks. In Era 2, the block reward remains constant at 384 for a period, then halves every 26,400 blocks (approximately 6 months) to 192, 96, 48, and 24. In Era 3, the block reward continues to halve indefinitely every 1,051,200 blocks (approximately 2 years) to 12, 6, and so on.

**User:**
That's interesting. I've also heard that there's an accelerated reward curve for mining and staking during the first 5 months of Verus's operation. What's the purpose of that?

**AI Assistant:**
The accelerated reward curve during the first 5 months is designed to contribute to a more stable value growth in the Verus currency, without any unusual risk of dumping by any single party. It incentivizes miners and stakers to support the long-term success of the Verus network and project.

**User:**
Another thing I've come across is time-locked coinbase transactions during the first two months of Verus's operation. What's the purpose of those?

**AI Assistant:**
The time-locked coinbase transactions during the first two months are designed to provide a smooth release of the Verus currency supply, as well as an incentive to all coin holders to support the long-term success of the Verus network and project. These transactions prevent spending, staking, or transferring of the coins for a period that varies from approximately 3 months after the genesis block to 2 years and 3 months.

**User:**
Finally, I've heard about the VerusHash algorithm. Can you tell me more about it?

**AI Assistant:**
The VerusHash algorithm is a CPU-only algorithm designed to be quantum secure and maximize performance on modern CPUs. It was designed to be CPU-optimized, but the Verus developers recognize that it is possible for someone to develop a GPU or ASIC-based miner that could be superior to CPUs in the future.
What is the block reward schedule for Verus, and how does it change over time?

The block reward schedule for Verus is divided into Eras. In Era 1, the block reward rises linearly from 0 to 384 over the first 10,080 blocks. In Era 2, the block reward remains constant at 384 for a period, then halves every 26,400 blocks (approximately 6 months) to 192, 96, 48, and 24. In Era 3, the block reward continues to halve indefinitely every 1,051,200 blocks (approximately 2 years) to 12, 6, and so on.

chedule is as follows:
Era 1:
Block 0 - 10080 reward: 0 to 384, rising linearly and changing each block
Era 2:
Block 10080 - 53279 reward: 384
Block 53280 - 96479 reward: 192
Block 96480 - 139679 reward: 96
Block 139680 - 182879 reward: 48
Block 182880 - 226079 reward: 24
Era 3:
Block 226080 - 1277279 reward: 24
Block 1277280 - 2328479 reward: 12
Block 2328480 - 3379679 reward: 6
. . . halving indefinitely every 1051200 blocks (approximately 2 years)
We also added another fair twist on the launch that we believe will contribute to a more
stable value growth in the Verus currency, without any unusual risk of dumping by any single
party. During the first 5 months, Verus will have an accelerated reward curve for mining
and staking, with a halving every month. During the first two months, when the block
rewards are at or above 192 Verus, mined blocks will have time locked coinbase transactions,
preventing spending, staking, or transferring of those coins for a period that varies from
approximately 3 months after the genesis block, based on numbers of blocks, to 2 years and
3 months. These time locked coins provide a smooth release of the Verus currency supply as
well as incentive to all of their owners to support the long term success of the Verus network
and project.
From the very beginning of its operation, Verus operated with a dual proof of stake /
proof of work mechanism for all participants. Verus mining with the VerusHash algorithm,
as of this point, is a CPU-only algorithm, designed with a Haraka512 V2 [30] core to be
quantum secure and to maximize performance on modern CPUs. While VerusHash was
designed to be CPU-optimized and did not begin life with GPU or ASIC miners capable of
beating CPUs in its mining, the Verus developers have no illusions that it is possible someone
might develop either a GPU or ASIC-based miner that could be meaningfully superior to
CPUs.
What is the purpose of the accelerated reward curve for mining and staking during the first 5 months of Verus's operation?

The accelerated reward curve during the first 5 months is designed to contribute to a more stable value growth in the Verus currency, without any unusual risk of dumping by any single party. It incentivizes miners and stakers to support the long-term success of the Verus network and project.
